RELATIVE MOTION
What's moving here?
idk, what defines something as moving?
Well, one might say that something is moving if it is not staying fixed to to some point on the Earth's surface.
And that would definitely be very useful for working out things like how quickly you can get somewhere.
But is the Earth moving?
The answer is yes, and no... relatively.
Let's take a look at the solar system.
You can't see or feel the Earth moving because your moving with it.
In other words, you and the earth are both stationary relative to each other (when your standing on the ground).
So motion is relative?
The motion of one thing is only measurable in relation to something else.
In fact, everything is either moving or stationary relative to everything else in the universe.
You can choose to measure the motion something relative to anything else, regardless of size, and you'll measure different speeds for each.
The speed, velocities and accelerations of the ball from the first demo are measured relative to the box the ball's in.
If you scroll or move your computer around, those values won't change.
FRAME OF REFERENCE
The point which you observe from is called your frame of reference.
Galilean invariance.
Newton's laws of motion are the same in all inertial reference frames.
What are Newton's laws of motion?
Three statements that dictate the movement of things.
1. inertia, 2. acceleration, 3. interacting bodies.
we'll take a look at the first two, the third isn't so relative here.
Inertia: things won't change motion (accelerate) unless something pushes or pulls them.

An inertial reference frame is a non accelerating reference frame.
In inertial reference frames, everything works normally.
You could play tennis on planes or
But how can a reference frame be accelerating if all motion is relative? And why does it matter?
Here it gets a bit tricky.
Cars and other things accelerate because there is some kind of pushing or pulling force that isn’t being evenly opposed.
This is what Newton's second law states.
This force is localised, it only acts on a certain bit of it.
Subsequently there is a chain reaction where that bit pushes everything it encounters, and those bits push everything they encounter and so on.
If you’re sitting in a vehicle, you feel the seat pushing you forwards.
If you're standing, there is nothing to push you and so you get swept off your feet as the floor accelerates underneath you.
is this uneven force acting on an accelerating body that makes the laws of motion act differently.
It’s a different story with acceleration due to gravity though, which we’ll get to later.
SPECIAL RELATIVITY
Albert Einstein
1905
Theory
Einstein's theory of special relativity builds from two postulates
to construct a totally mind bending explanation
for how space and time work
Everything talked about up to this point is known as classical physics
Everything from this point on falls under the category of modern physics.
First Postulate.
All laws of physics (not just motion) are consistent across every inertial reference frame.
that's acceptable, not too much of an extension from the galilean invariance.
Second Postulate.
The speed of light in a vacuum always moves at a constant speed of c in every inertial refrence frame.
let's explore that a bit.
LIGHT WEIRDNESS
light has a speed.
That speed, c, is precisely 299 792 458 m/s. Always (in a vacuum).
that's around 7.5 laps of the earth every second
The speed was derived in the work of James Maxwell on electromagnetism in the nineteenth century
Following the first postulate, the laws of physics are the same in all inertial reference frames,
including the laws of electromagnetism, from which the constant speed of light is derived.
The issue is this breaks galilean relativity
Imagine two rockets, rocket Angus and rocket Barry.
Speed of someone walking forwards on rocket Angus as viewed from rocket Barry.
(walk speed relative to Barry) = (walk speed relative to Angus) + (Angus speed relative to Barry).
Imagine the speed difference between rocket Barry and rocket Angus is 150 000 000 m/s, or about half the speed of light.
If light was emitted forwards (with speed c) on rocket Angus (with speed 0.5c), then the speed observed on Barry would be 1.5c
but the speed of light is constant from every inertial reference frame...
So uh
